questions.text: Which of the following tests is most specific for confirming a diagnosis of syphilis?
Which of the following statements correctly describes the two forms of Chlamydia?

options.label: A
options.text: The Elementary Body (EB) is the replicative form, while the Reticulate Body (RB) is the infectious form.

options.label: B
options.text: The Elementary Body (EB) is the infectious form that enters host cells, while the Reticulate Body (RB) is the replicative form.

options.label: C
options.text: The Elementary Body (EB) and Reticulate Body (RB) are extracellular forms.

options.label: D
options.text: The Reticulate Body (RB) is the metabolically inactive form.

questions.correct_answer: B. The Elementary Body (EB) is the infectious form that enters host cells, while the Reticulate Body (RB) is the replicative form.
questions.explanation:
Elementary Body (EB)

Reticulate Body (RB)

Infectious form

The small, extracellular, and metabolically inactive form.

The larger, intracellular, and metabolically active form.

Role

It enters the host cell by endocytosis.

Once inside the host cell, the EB transforms into the RB.

Characteristics

It is designed to survive outside the host cell and initiate infection.

RBs are responsible for replication within a host cell.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding Ehrlichiosis?
questions.correct_answer: A. It primarily affects the monocytes

questions.text: A 30 year old female patient presented with high fever, severe headache, myalgia and anemia on returning from Brazil recently. A suspicion of Oroya fever was made. What is the causative organism and vector involved in this disease?
A veterinarian who had been working in an animal research facility came was suspected to have Q fever. What is the false statement regarding the disease?

options.label: A
options.text: The infective organism shows affinity to the vascular endothelium

options.label: B
options.text: Produces donut shaped granulomas in histopathology

options.label: C
options.text: Chronic infection can present as infective endocarditis

options.label: D
options.text: Transmission is by inhalation of aerosols

questions.correct_answer: A. The infective organism shows affinity to the vascular endothelium
questions.explanation:
Q fever

Causative agent

Coxiella burnetii (Zoonosis transmitted from animals to humans)

Mode of spread

  • By inhalation of aerosols from infected animals or their products. (Option D is ruled out)
  • Other modes include consumption of unpasteurized milk and ingestion of other infected animals or their products.
  • High risk groups include farmers, veterinarians, and workers involved in slaughtering.
  • High-risk areas include animal research facilities that do not have adequate personnel protection.

Pathophysiology
  • C.burnetii shows affinity to the reticuloendothelial system, especially the alveolar macrophages.
  • They are known to grow at low pH and even resist lysosomal enzymes.
  • In its growth cycle Coxiella includes a form that is resistant to drying and other environmental conditions much like a bacterial spore( but not actual spores as in Bacillus or Clostridium species).
  • These spores are inhaled as aerosols.
  • They are known to produce donut shaped granuloma/ fibrin ring granuloma in histopathology sections. (Option B is ruled out)

Clinical features
  • It usually begins at an average of 20 days after inhalation with abrupt onset of fever, chills, and headache without rash.
  • A mild, dry, hacking cough and patchy interstitial pneumonia may occur as like in atypical pneumonia.
  • Hepatosplenomegaly and abnormal liver function tests are common. Complications such as myocarditis, pericarditis, and encephalitis are rare.
  • Chronic infection is also rare, but particularly important when it takes the form of culture negative infective endocarditis. (Option C is ruled out)

Investigations
  • The diagnosis of Q fever is usually made by demonstrating high or rising titers of antibodies to the Q fever antigen by enzyme immunoassay.
  • Single positive blood culture for Coxiella burnetii or phase I IgG antibody titer of >1:800 to diagnose infective endocarditis.
  • Molecular techniques such as PCR for C.burnetii DNA.

Treatment

  • Acute Q fever: Doxycycline is the drug of choice; given for 14 days. Quinolones are also effective.
  • Chronic Q fever: Hydroxychloroquine is added to alkalinize the phagolysosome and to render doxycycline bactericidal against the organism.
  • Vaccines have been shown to have a protective effect for heavily exposed workers. (Q-vax in Australia)

questions.text: A hiker had recently returned from a forest expedition with complaints of high grade fever along with a painless blackish crusted lesion at the site of insect bite.The following insect was identified by him. What will a Weil-Felix test show for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Disease

Agglutination Test Result

Epidemic and endemic typhus

Mainly agglutinates with OX19; sometimes with OX2 (Option A ruled out)

Tick-borne Spotted Fever

Antibodies to both OX19 and OX2 elevated.(Option B ruled out)

Scrub Typhus

Raised antibodies to OXK(Option D)

Rickettsial Pox, Q Fever, Ehrlichiosis, Bartonellosis

Negative test

questions.text: A 35 year old male patient was admitted in the medicine ward with complaints of high grade fever, maculopapular rash and a skin lesion at the site of insect bite as shown below. He gives a recent history of hiking in a scrub forest. What is the false statement regarding the probable disease?

options.label: B
options.text: Maculopapular rash involves the palms and soles

options.label: C
options.text: Transovarial transmission of the causative organism occurs through chiggers

options.label: D
options.text: The drug of choice is doxycycline

questions.correct_answer: B. Maculopapular rash involves the palms and soles
questions.explanation:
Scrub typhus

Causative agent

Orientia tsutsugamushi - It differs from Rickettsia both genetically and by its cell wall composition i.e. it lacks lipopolysaccharide layer. (Option A ruled out)

Vector

Chiggers (larvae of trombiculid mite)

Pathophysiology
  • Scrub typhus is so named because it occurs in scrub vegetation i.e. low-lying trees and bushes.
  • The bite of infected trombiculid mites transmits it.
  • Among all stages of mite, the larvae (called chiggers) are the only stage that feed on humans. Hence, scrub typhus is also called chiggerosis.
  • Mites can maintain the organisms through transovarial transmission. (Option C ruled out)
  • Orientia tsutsugamushi infects mononuclear cells but still produces fever and rash.

Clinical features

  • The classic presentation of scrub typhus consists of triad of an eschar (at the site of bite), regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash sparing palms and soles.
  • Non-specific manifestations may appear early such as fever, headache, myalgia, cough, and gastrointestinal symptoms.
  • Complications such as encephalitis and interstitial pneumonia may occur rarely in the late stage (due to vascular injury).

Investigations

  • The Weil-Felix test shows OX K+ only.

Treatment

  • Doxycycline is the drug choice. (Option D ruled out)
  • Azithromycin is given alternatively and the drug of choice in children and pregnant women.

questions.text: A middle aged female patient presented with high grade fever, maculo-papular rashes primarily affecting the trunk extending to the extremities sparing the palms and soles. She also mentions that there are a lot of rats in her area. A Weil-Felix test showed positive OX 19 and OX 2 antibodies. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Endemic typhus

Causative agent

Rickettsia typhi (It is endemic worldwide, especially in warm coastal areas having high rat infestations).

Vector

Rat flea (Xenopsylla cheopis)

Pathophysiology
  • It is transmitted by rubbing or scratching on the skin or inhalation of flea’s dried faeces, less frequently by the flea bite.
  • The incubation period is 1–2 weeks. They also show tropism for vascular endothelium.
  • Focal areas of endothelial proliferation cause the rash and petechial lesions, perivascular infiltration leading to thrombosis and leakage of red blood cells into the surrounding tissues.

Clinical features

  • Symptoms are similar to epidemic typhus but milder and rarely fatal.
  • Fever, headache, and rash begin 1 to 2 weeks after the bite. Rash involves the trunk and primarily spreads to the extremities, sparing the palms and soles.

Investigations

  • The diagnostic test of choice is serology i.e. rise in antibody titre.
  • Weil-Felix test showing both Ox19+ and Ox2+.

Treatment

  • Doxycycline is the drug of choice.

questions.text: During a medical camp at a newly established refugee centre, a medical officer observes several patients presenting with high-grade fever, headache, and macular rashes primarily affecting the trunk and extending to the extremities. He also learns about a widespread louse infestation within the centre. What might be the diagnosis and the likely causative agent in this situation?

options.label: D
options.text: Rocky Mountain spotted fever and Rickettsia rickettsia

questions.correct_answer: B. Epidemic typhus and Rickettsia prowazekii
questions.explanation:
Epidemic typhus

Causative agent

Rickettsia prowazekii (It is the only rickettsial disease that can occur as an epidemic)

Vector

Louse

Pathophysiology
  • It occurs during conditions favourable to human body lice infestation such as in refugee and famine camps.(crowding, infrequent bathing)
  • The cycle starts with R.prowazekii circulating in a patient’s blood during an acute febrile infection.
  • After 5 to 10 days of incubation, large numbers of rickettsiae appear in its infective faeces.
  • Since the louse defecates when it feeds, the organisms can be rubbed into the louse bite wounds when the host scratches the site.
  • Dried louse faeces are also infectious through the mucous membranes of the eye or respiratory tract. The louse dies of its infection in 1 to 3 weeks.
  • Most of Rickettsiae, including Rickettsia prowazekii, shows tropism for vascular endothelium.
  • They multiply in the endothelial cells, leading to increased vascular permeability, hypovolemia, and hypotension.
  • Focal areas of endothelial proliferation cause the rash and petechial lesions, perivascular infiltration that leads to thrombosis, and leakage of red blood cells into the surrounding tissues.

Clinical features

  • Fever, headache, and rash begin 1 to 2 weeks after the bite.
  • In the majority of cases, a maculopapular rash appears first on the trunk and then spreads centrifugally to the extremities, sparing the palms and soles.
  • Eschar is absent at the site of entry.
  • Headache, malaise, and myalgia are prominent components of the illness.
  • Complications include myocarditis and central nervous system dysfunction.
  • In untreated disease, the fatality rate increases with age as much as 60%.

Investigations

  • The diagnostic test of choice is serology i.e. rise in antibody titre.
  • Weil-Felix test showing both OX 19+ and OX 2+.

Treatment

  • Treatment with doxycycline is effective.
  • Louse control is the best means of prevention and is particularly important in controlling epidemics.
  • No effective vaccine is available.

questions.text: Match the following diseases with their respective vectors. Disease Vector 1. Scrub typhus a) Hard Tick 2. Epidemic typhus b) Trombiculid mite 3. Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever c) Rat flea 4. Endemic typhus d) Louse
questions.explanation:
Disease

Vector

1. Scrub typhus

b) Trombiculid mite

2. Epidemic typhus

d) Louse

3. Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever

a) Hard Tick

4. Endemic typhus

c) Rat flea

questions.text: Which of the following rickettsial bacteria specifically target granulocytes in their pathogenesis?
Which of the following statements is true regarding Chlamydia pneumoniae and Chlamydia psittaci?

options.label: A
options.text: Both are primarily transmitted through respiratory droplets from person to person.

options.label: D
options.text: The incubation period for Chlamydia pneumoniae is longer than that of Chlamydia psittaci.

questions.correct_answer: C. C.pneumoniae has only TWAR strain.
questions.explanation:
Chlamydia pneumoniae

Chlamydia psittaci

Only one strain (TWAR strain) (Option C)

Many serotypes

Respiratory infections (pneumonia, bronchitis, sinusitis)

Psittacosis (a zoonotic infection)

Primarily through respiratory droplets and person-to-person contact.

Primarily from infected birds (mainly parrots and pigeons) through inhalation of aerosolised particles. (Option A)

1 to 3 weeks of incubation period.(Option D)

2 to 4 weeks of incubation

Doxycycline is the first line treatment.

Doxycycline is the first-line treatment.

It also causes asthma, sarcoidosis and infectious atherosclerosis. (Option B)

Mainly cause only pneumonia.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Lymphogranuloma Venereum (LGV) is true?

options.label: A
options.text: LGV is caused by serotypes A, B, C of Chlamydia trachomatis.

options.label: B
options.text: The primary lesion in LGV is typically a painful genital ulcer.

options.label: C
options.text: Doxycycline is the first-line treatment for LGV.

options.label: D
options.text: LGV is primarily transmitted through blood transfusions.

questions.correct_answer: C. Doxycycline is the first-line treatment for LGV.

questions.text: Which of the following serotypes of Chlamydia trachomatis is primarily associated with causing trachoma?

options.label: A
options.text: D, E, F, G, H, I, J, K

questions.explanation:
Serotypes

Associated Infections

A, B, Ba, C

(Option B)
  • Trachoma: Eye infections leading to blindness.
  • M/C form is B

D, E, F, G, H, I, J, K

(Option A)
  • Genital Infections: Non gonococcal Urethritis, cervicitis, and pelvic inflammatory disease (PID).
  • Infant pneumonia.

L1, L2, L3

(Option C)
  • Lymphogranuloma Venereum (LGV): A more severe STI characterized by swollen lymph nodes and genital ulcers.
  • M/C form is L2

questions.text: Match the following species of Treponema with the respective diseases they cause. 1. Treponema pallidum I. Pinta 2. Treponema endemicum II. Venereal syphillis 3. Treponema pertenue III. Yaws 4. Treponema carateum IV. Endemic syphillis (Bejel)
Which of the following features is false regarding Chlamydia?

options.label: A
options.text: It is an obligate intracellular organism

questions.correct_answer: C. Cell wall rich in peptidoglycan

questions.text: What is the preferred diagnostic test for confirming a case of leptospirosis?
Which of the following statements on leptospirosis is false?
questions.correct_answer: D. Majority develop into Weil’s disease
questions.explanation:
Causative Agent
  • Leptospira interrogans (bacteria) (Option C ruled out)

Transmission
  • Zoonotic disease (Option A ruled out)
  • Indirect: Contact with water, moist soil, or surfaces contaminated with animal urine.
  • Direct: Contact with urine or parturition products from infected animals.

Pathogenesis Phases
  • Septicemic Phase: Entry through mucosa or skin, dissemination via bloodstream to organs.
  • Immune Phase: Antibodies develop, spirochetes disappear from blood; antigen-antibody complexes form, and renal colonization occurs.

Clinical Syndromes
  • Mild Anicteric Illness: Seen in 90% of cases, flu-like symptoms with fever, headache, conjunctival suffusion, nausea, vomiting, and myalgia.
  • Weil’s Disease: Severe icteric illness (Option B ruled out) in 10% of cases(Option D); rapid progression, fatality rate of 5-15%.

questions.text: Match the Borellia species with its mode of transmission Species Transmission 1.Borrelia vincentii a.Direct contact 2.Borrelia recurrentis b.Tick-borne 3.Borrelia hermsii c.Louse-borne
questions.explanation:
Species

Disease

Transmission

Borrelia recurrentis

Relapsing fever (epidemic)-illnesses characterized by recurrent fevers, chills, and malaise.

Louse-borne

Borrelia duttonii

Relapsing fever (endemic)

Tick-borne

Borrelia hermsii

Relapsing fever (endemic)

Tick-borne

Borrelia vincentii

Vincent’s angina- acute necrotizing ulcerative gingivostomatitis

Direct contact

questions.text: Which of the following is the pathogen responsible for Lyme disease?
questions.explanation:
Cause

Borrelia burgdorferi

Stages of Disease
  1. Stage 1 (Localized): Erythema migrans (EM) skin lesion, expanding annular rash.

  1. Stage 2 (Disseminated): Fever, headache, myalgia, arthralgia, lymphadenopathy, possible meningeal or cardiac involvement.
  2. Stage 3 (Persistent): Chronic arthritis, polyneuropathy, encephalopathy, and acrodermatitis.

Vector

Ixodid ticks (Ixodes dammini and related species).

 

Laboratory Diagnosis
  • Culture: Requires modified Kelley's (BSK) medium, 33°C incubation for 2+ weeks (difficult to use in routine diagnosis).
  • Serology: ELISA and IF tests, with immunoblotting for confirmation; IgM appears first, followed by IgG.

Cross-Reactivity

False-positive reactions may occur in syphilis serology

Treatment

Doxycycline, amoxicillin, and cefuroxime.

questions.text: Which of the following statements on the Rapid Plasma Reagin test is false?

options.label: B
options.text: Results are easily seen with the naked eye

options.label: C
options.text: Unheated serum or plasma can be used

options.label: D
options.text: Can be used for testing CSF

questions.correct_answer: D. Can be used for testing CSF

questions.text: Which of the following statements on the VDRL test is false?

options.label: C
options.text: Can be false positive in leprosy

options.label: D
options.text: Reaction is observed under naked eye

questions.correct_answer: D. Reaction is observed under naked eye
questions.explanation:
Antigen Used

Purified lipid extract of beef heart (cardiolipin), with added lecithin and cholesterol (Option A ruled out)

Test Procedure
  • The inactivated serum (heated at 56°C for 30 minutes) is mixed with cardiolipin antigen on a special slide.
  • The slide is rotated for 4 minutes.
  • Cardiolipin remains uniform in normal serum but clumps with reagin antibody.(Option B ruled out)

  • Reaction observed under a low-power microscope.(Option D)

False positives found in

  • Infections, injuries, or inflammation.(Acute)
  • SLE, leprosy(Option C ruled out), malaria, relapsing fever, mononucleosis, hepatitis, tropical eosinophilia, and other collagen diseases.(Chronic)

questions.text: What is the appearance of Treponema pallidum in dark field microscopy?
questions.explanation:
Specimen Collection
  • Lesion cleaned with gauze soaked in warm saline.
  • Margins gently scraped to abrade superficial epithelium.
  • Gentle pressure applied to the lesion base to collect exudate (prevent blood admixture).
  • Serum collected for serology; CSF for neurosyphilis.

Dark ground microscopy

 
  • Exudate collected and placed under a coverslip.
  • Examined with dark ground microscopy.
  • T. pallidum identified by slender, tightly coiled spiral structure showing slow movement.

Silver Impregnation Staining
  • Fontana’s method is used for staining smear films.
  • Levaditi’s method is preferred for tissue sections. 

impregnation technique" data-author="" data-hash="10254" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/t9mLdodZo9KwWijf9KIl1744550493.png" />

questions.text: A 2-year-old infant is brought to the pediatric clinic for evaluation of persistent nasal congestion and a rash. On examination, the infant has a bloody nasal discharge, a diffuse rash with scaly lesions on the trunk, and notable dental abnormalities, including peg-shaped incisors. Which of the following findings is the most characteristic feature to identify the disease?
questions.correct_answer: B. Hutchinson's teeth and bone abnormalities

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents to the clinic with complaints of a widespread rash and flu-like symptoms that have been present for the past week. She reports that the rash started on her trunk and has now spread to her arms and legs, along with lesions on her oral mucosa. She also mentions experiencing mild sore throat and fatigue. She has a history of multiple sexual partners in the past year. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 45-year-old man presents to the clinic with complaints of progressive weakness and difficulty walking over the past few months. He has a history of untreated syphilis 15 years ago, which he believed had resolved. On examination, the patient exhibits significant degeneration in his right knee. Neurological examination reveals decreased proprioception and vibratory sensation in the lower extremities. Which diagnostic test would be most useful in confirming the suspicion of tertiary syphilis in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) for Treponema pallidum

options.label: B
options.text: CSF Venereal Disease Research Laboratory (VDRL) test

options.label: C
options.text: Lumbar puncture for cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis

questions.correct_answer: B. CSF Venereal Disease Research Laboratory (VDRL) test

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the clinic with painless ulcers on his genital region that have been present for about three weeks as shown below. He denies any associated symptoms such as fever, malaise, or lymphadenopathy. His sexual history reveals multiple partners in the past year. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the clinical presentation?
